title: Conductors - charge on three metal plates

content.question: Three identical metal plates are arranged with parallel surfaces separated by relatively small distances, as shown in the figure. The top plate has a net charge <math alttext="positive lowercase q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>+</mo><mi>q</mi></mstyle></math>, the middle plate is uncharged, and the bottom plate has net charge <math alttext="negative lowercase q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>âˆ’</mo><mi>q</mi></math>. The top plate is brought close to the middle plate, so they touch and stay on contact. How do the charge distributions on the top and middle plates change after they touch?

choices.label: The <math alttext="positive lowercase q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>+</mo><mi>q</mi></mstyle></math> charge is distributed evenly throughout the top and middle plates.

The top plate keeps <math alttext="positive lowercase q over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>+</mo><mi>q</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mstyle></math> on its top surface and transfers <math alttext="positive lowercase q over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>+</mo><mi>q</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mstyle></math> to the bottom surface of the middle plate.

The charge <math alttext="positive lowercase q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>+</mo><mi>q</mi></mstyle></math> remains at the boundary between the top and middle plate.

The net charge of the top plate <math alttext="positive lowercase q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>+</mo><mi>q</mi></mstyle></math> goes to the bottom surface of the middle plate.

content.answer: The net charge of the top plate <math alttext="positive lowercase q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>+</mo><mi>q</mi></mstyle></math> goes to the bottom surface of the middle plate.
